MyJnonZj.title: Production technique of bimetal composite pipe by long launder centrifugal casting
MyJnonZj.abstract: The production technique and main parameters of bimetal composite pipe-compounding high chromium cast iron in inner wall of steel pipe, by long launder centrifugal casting are presented. Using the technique can produce longer and thinner bimetal composite, and the compounding thickness is uniform. The service performance and economical efficiency of the composite pipe are enhanced greatly.

bozBlcLy.title: Microstructures and wear-resistant properties of in-situ WCP/W wire hybrid reinforced iron matrix composites via electromagnetic field
bozBlcLy.abstract: In the paper, tungsten carbide (WC) particles can be in-situ synthesized by applying electromagnetic field to the system consisting of tungsten wires and gray cast iron melt at 1573 K. The microstructures and wear-resistant properties of composites reinforced by both WC particles and the residual tungsten wires were investigated by XRD, SEM, EDS, micro-hardness and pin-on-disc wear measurements. The results show that, with enhancing frequencies of electromagnetic field from 0 to 5 KHz, the amounts of in-situ WC particles increased and of the residual tungsten wires gradually decreased until tungsten wires completely reacted. Due to the higher hardness of in-situ WC p(2100-223IHV0. 1) and the strong interfacial bonding, the composites displayed an excellent wear-resistant properties. When the frequency was 5 kHz, the wear loss for the composite fabricated was optimal and 2. 69 times lower than that of reference samples.

8EVaG2ju.title: Iron matrix composite reinforced by hybrid of in-situ WC particles and tungsten wires
8EVaG2ju.abstract: The in-situ synthesis of WC particles through reaction between tungsten wires and carbon atoms was observed by exerting an electromagnetic field to the system consisting of tungsten wires and melt of gray cast iron. The microstructures of the composites were studied by means of SEM, EDS and XRD. The results show that when the frequency of the electromagnetic field is 4 kHz and the current is 15 A, the WC particles are in-situ synthesized and distribute around the residual tungsten wires. Iron matrix composites reinforced hybridly by in-situ WC particles and the residual tungsten wires are obtained. The results of two-body abrasive test shows that the wear resistance of the hybrid reinforced iron matrix composite is 2.5 times higher than that of the reference sample, this is attributed to the higher hardness of in-situ WC particles and their dispersive distribution in the matrix.

tPZwuZ27.title: Effects of heat treatment on mechanical properties and microstructure of tungsten wire reinforced gray cast iron matrix composites
tPZwuZ27.abstract: In this study,grey cast iron matrix composites reinforced by different volume fractions of tungsten fibers(Vr=0.95%,1.90%,2.85%,3.80%)were investigated in as-cast and under the heat treatment temperatures of 1,000℃and 1,100℃.The microstructure and mechanical properties of the composites were analyzed and tested by means of SEM,micro-hardness tester and three-point bend testing.The results show that with increasing of the volume fraction of tungsten fibers,the composites reinforced by the tungsten fiber have higher flexural strength and modulus than that of cast iron without reinforcement,and the flexural strength increases with the increasing of heat treatment temperatures.Due to diffusion reaction between matrix and reinforcing phases,the process of heat treatment,the number of graphite flakes in the matrix seemingly becomes lower;and some hard carbide particles are formed around the residual tungsten fibers.Not only does the hardness of both matrix and reinforcement change tremendously,but also the region of reinforcement is also extended from the original 0.11 mm to 0.19 mm in radius.

swdl1874.title: In-situ synthesis of WC particles via electromagnetic field
swdl1874.abstract: Applying an electromagnetic field, tungsten carbide particles (WCp) could be in-situ synthesized through reaction between tungsten atoms and carbon atom groups from system consisting of tungsten wires and gray cast iron melt at 1300°C. The iron matrix composites reinforced by both in-situ synthesis of WC particles and the residual tungsten wires were obtained. The microstructures of composites were characterized by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectrometer. The results indicate that, under the current of 15 A, with enhancement of electromagnetic field frequency, the amount of in-situ WCp gradually increases, and the amount of the residual tungsten wires continuously decreases. When the frequency reaches 5 kHz, tungsten wires can be reacted completely. The electromagnetic field can accelerate mass transfer and elemental diffusion in iron molten, and contribute quickly to form a series of small Fe-W-C ternary zones containing high tungsten content around the tungsten wires, and improve the kinetic condition of in-situ formation of WCp. The gaps among WCp synthesized play a role of the filter which can lower the elements diffusive rate.

dEwDjm39.title: In-situ synthesis of WCp/tungsten wire reinforced iron matrix composite under electromagnetic field
dEwDjm39.abstract: Tungsten carbide (WC) particles were in-situ synthesized using tungsten wires and gray cast iron molten at 1573 K under electromagnetic field and WCp/tungsten wire reinforced iron matrix composite was fabricated. The experimental results indicate that the reinforcement formed in the composite depends on frequency of the electromagetic field, when the frequency of electromagnetic field is below 4 kHz, the composite is reinforced by both in-situ synthesized WCp and residual tungsten wires, when the frequency is 4 kHz, tungsten wires are completely reacted and the composite is reinforced by in-situ synthesized WCp. The electromagnetic field accelerates mass transfer process in the molten, contributes to quickly form local Fe-W-C ternary zones with high tungsten content around the tungsten wires and promotes the synthesis of WCp. However, the gaps of the inter-WCp particles play a role of a filter which hinders the diffusion of elements. The composite exhibits high wear resistance due to higher hardness WCp and its dispersive distribution in the matrix.

qBKTAPPL.title: In situ fabrication of titanium carbide particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites
qBKTAPPL.abstract: Titanium carbide (TiC) particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites were prepared by in situ fabrication method combining an infiltration casting with a subsequent heat treatment. The effects of different heat treatment times (0, 1, 6 and 11 h) at 1138 °C on the phase evolution, microstructural features, and properties of the composites were investigated. The as-prepared composites were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and microhardness and wear resistance tests. The XRD results showed that the composites consisted of graphite, α-iron and titanium carbide after heat treatment at 1138 °C for 11 h. The SEM observation revealed that the formed TiC particulates were homogenously distributed in the iron matrix. The average microhardness of the composite heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h increased depending upon the region: 209 HV 0.1 (iron matrix) < 787 HV 0.1 (titanium wire) < 2667 HV 0.1 (composite region). After being heat treated at 1138 °C for 11 h, the composite indicated no considerable change in microhardness value, and the average microhardness of the composite region was about 2354 HV 0.1 . The highest microhardness value obtained for the composite region was due to the formation of titanium carbide particulates as reinforcement phase within the iron matrix. Relative wear resistance was determined by a pin-on-disc wear test technique under different loads, and as a result, the composites containing higher volume fraction of hard titanium carbide particulates presented higher wear resistance compared with the unreinforced gray cast iron. Keywords A. Metal matrix C. Casting E. Wear 1 Introduction A rapid technological development, in turn, demands various kinds of advanced materials with a set of favorable properties that meet the modern requirements. As an advanced material, metal matrix composites (MMCs) reinforced with ceramic particulates have been widely used in numerous applications. Up to date, the iron- and steel-based composites have been produced through the different processes, namely, powder metallurgy, conventional casting, self-propagating high-temperature synthesis, in situ reaction technique, etc. As a single step process, powder metallurgy has however intrinsic limitations for product size, cost and quality. During the last decade, much attention has been paid to the preparation of metal matrix composites by a method that combines powder metallurgy with an in situ reaction technique. This combined method allows eliminating the interface incompatibility of the matrix with the reinforcement phase. A conventional casting is also used in manufacturing of metal matrix composites reinforced by ceramic particulates but the ceramic particulates in the matrix are uneven because of the density difference between the matrix and the reinforcement phase; moreover, the volume fraction of the reinforcement phase is limited. Metal matrix composites reinforced with ceramic particulates can also be produced by self-propagating high-temperature synthesis [1] but they cannot be directly applied as a structural material due to their porosity and looseness. In addition, it is difficult to control the reaction speed during this process. So far, in situ reaction technique has been considered to be one of the most promising methods for the production of metal matrix composites because of the fine size and thermodynamic stability of the ceramic particulates in the matrix as well as a strong interfacial bonding between the matrix and the reinforcement phase, providing higher mechanical properties. The most common carbide ceramic materials employed as reinforcement phases for various iron and steel matrices are TiC, WC, VC, B 4 C, etc. Among them, titanium carbide (TiC) with the Vickers hardness of 2895–3200 HV is one of the most suitable reinforcements for the iron and steel matrices because of its availability, high hardness, high melting point, and good thermodynamic stability. The most important is that the TiC reinforcement phase can be chemically wetted by the iron matrix. Recent studies have showed that the wetting angle θ between the TiC and molten iron is less than 50°, even at high temperatures and in different atmospheres [2,3] . Till now, several methods have been successfully applied in producing the TiC/Fe composites by a combined in situ technique [4,5] . Feng et al. [6] demonstrated the in situ synthesis of the TiC/Fe composite with low volume fraction of TiC by reaction casting. Li et al. [7] fabricated homogenously distributed TiC particulates with the size of ∼1 μm in the iron-based matrix, using ferrotitanium and carbon black powders, by a combined method of spark plasma sintering with an in situ reaction. Wang and Wang [8] also produced the TiC/Fe composite by a process combining powder metallurgy with the in situ reaction technique. Although a number of reports on the in situ synthesis of TiC particulates in the iron matrix, here we present a new process combining an infiltration casting with a subsequent heat treatment for the fabrication of the TiC/Fe composites. The present report mainly emphasizes on the effects of different heat treatment times (0, 1, 6 and 11 h) at 1138 °C on the phase evolution, microstructural features, and properties of the TiC/Fe composites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation For the in situ fabrication of titanium carbide particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites, gray cast iron and titanium wires (0.6 mm and 99.99 % purity) were employed as carbon and titanium sources, respectively. The chemical composition of gray cast iron (wt.%) is Fe–4.22C–0.58Si–0.268Mn–0.224P–0.024S. First, a gray cast iron mold was produced in rectangular shape, and a number of holes were inversely drilled ( ∼ 0.6 mm) on both sides, with a targeted distance of 3 mm between the holes. The titanium wires were parallelly passed through the existing holes on both sides and firmly fixed with the mold, and then the as-prepared mold was inserted into a graphite mold. Molten gray cast iron was produced in a medium-frequency induction furnace and poured into the prepared mold at 1450 °C. The specimen was immediately covered with quartz sand to avoid the crack generation and cooled down to room temperature naturally. Afterwards, the specimen was cut into the size of 10 mm × 10 mm × 25 mm by a numerically-controlled wire-cut EDM machine (Suzhou Nutac Electro Mechanic Co. Ltd., China). An appropriate heating temperature (1138 °C) of the sectioned sample was chosen considering the partial dissolution temperature of the titanium wire determined by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). The sectioned samples were subjected to heat treatment at 1138 °C for different dwelling times (0, 1, 6 and 11 h) in a horizontal tube furnace with a modest flow of argon gas and cooled down to room temperature naturally. 2.2 Characterization After being polished with diamond paste and etched with a 4% Nital solution, the microstructures of the as-prepared samples were examined using a JSM-5800 scanning electron microscope (SEM; JEOL, Japan) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected using a PW 1730 X-ray diffractometer (Philips, The Netherlands) with monochromated CuKα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA in the 2 θ range of 10–90°. Microhardness of the specimens was measured by a HDX-1000 digital microhardness tester (Taiming Test Co., China), which consisted of a square-based pyramidal diamond indenter with a 136° angle between two opposite faces. The static load applied was 50 g and the dwell time was 15 s. An average value of microhardness was taken from at least five different measurements. To determine an appropriate heating temperature, thermal measurements were performed on a Q600 SDT (TA Instruments, USA) for the specimen, with a 2.0 mm diameter and a 2.6 mm length, prepared from gray cast iron and titanium wire. The as-prepared specimen was heated at 10 °C/min up to a maximum temperature of 1200 °C with a 150 ml/min flow rate of argon gas and cooled down to room temperature. For abrasive wear resistance test, cylindrical pin specimens with the diameter of 6 mm and the length of 25 mm were sectioned, and a two-body abrasive wear test was performed on a ML-100 wear test machine (Zhangjiakou Xuan Ke Testing Machine Manufacturing Co. Ltd., China). The pin specimens were loaded against a rotating disc (25 rpm) covered with a 500 mesh alumina abrasive paper under the load of 5, 10, 15, 20 and 25 N. To ensure fresh supply of abrasive particles to the pin specimens, the worn alumina abrasive paper was replaced with the new one for every sliding distance of 20 m. The wear resistance test was repeated at least three times for each sample, and the weight losses of the pin specimens were measured in an electronic balance with an accuracy of 0.0001 g. Relative wear resistance β is used to evaluate the abrasive wear properties of the as-prepared composites, which can be obtained through the following process: (1) Δ V = Δ m ρ where Δ V is the abrasive volume, Δ m is the weight loss after abrasion, and ρ is the density of the testing material. (2) β = Δ V r Δ V c where β is the relative wear resistance, Δ V r is the abrasive volume of reference gray cast iron sample, and Δ V c is the abrasive volume of TiC particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites. 3 Results and discussion The thermal behavior of the specimen manufactured from gray cast iron and titanium wire is shown in Fig. 1 a. In the DSC curve, there are two endothermic peaks with relatively higher intensities centered at 755 °C and 1061 °C, two endothermic peaks with relatively lower intensities centered at 1121 °C and 1132 °C, and one exothermic peak centered at 1138 °C. According to the phase diagrams shown in Fig. 1b and c , the transformation of α-Fe to γ-Fe is observed as the first endothermic peak at 755 °C [9] , and the second endothermic peak at 1061 °C is due to the formation of the eutectic composition of titanium and iron [10] . The third (1121 °C) and fourth (1132 °C) endothermic peaks are associated with the melting of iron matrix and a partial dissolution of the titanium wire, respectively. The exothermic peak at 1138 °C is probably attributed to the formation of a new phase (TiC), resulted from the reaction between the carbon from gray cast iron and the titanium from the titanium wire [11] . From the thermal analysis of the specimen, it is found that the melting of the iron matrix and a partial dissolution of the titanium wire can be favored at 1138 °C. Therefore, the sectioned specimens are further heat treated at 1138 °C for different dwelling times (0, 1, 6 and 11 h) in the presence of argon gas. The SEM micrographs of the heat-treated samples are displayed in Fig. 2 as a function of heat treatment time. As can be seen in Fig. 2a–d , the diffusion region in the composite gradually increases with an increase in heat treatment time from 0 to 11 h, and the diameter of the metallic titanium wire contracts and eventually disappears. After being heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h, the composite region in the specimen can be readily divided into three apparent zones, as clearly discriminated in Fig. 2 c: inner (titanium wire), outer (iron matrix), and intermediate (diffusion region). It is obvious from Fig. 2 d that the titanium wires were completely melted after the heat treatment of the specimen at 1138 °C for 11 h, and more titanium atoms were diffused into the iron matrix that promoted the in situ formation of the titanium carbide particulates in the iron matrix. The XRD patterns of the titanium carbide particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites are represented in Fig. 3 as a function of heat treatment time. The XRD results confirm the presence of graphite (JCPDS card No. 26-1079), α-iron (JCPDS card No. 06-696), titanium carbide (JCPDS card No. 65-0971), and metallic titanium (JCPDS card No. 51-0631) in the samples heat treated at 1138 °C for 0 h, 1 h, and 6 h as predominant phases. In contrast, the XRD pattern of the sample heat treated at 1138 °C for 11 h shows no peak corresponding to the metallic titanium. By prolonging heat treatment time from 0 h to 11 h, the intensities of the graphite and the metallic titanium peaks decrease with the increase in the intensities of the newly-formed titanium carbide peaks. An abrupt disappearance of the diffraction peak of the metallic titanium after heat treatment at 1138 °C for 11 h proves that the titanium atoms were fully consumed for the reaction with graphite in the iron matrix; however, a little amount of unreacted graphite is still present. The titanium carbide particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites can be obtained under the current conditions along with the traces of unconsumed graphite. It is evident from Fig. 2 d that the titanium wires melted and reacted completely after heat treatment of the specimen at 1138 °C for 11 h, and so the titanium atoms were evenly diffused into the iron matrix, which could facilitate the formation of homogenously distributed titanium carbide particulates. The reaction region can be readily differentiated from the iron matrix with a circle zone, consisting of the in situ synthesized titanium carbide, which is incorporated with the iron matrix. Fig. 4 exhibits low and high magnification SEM images of that reaction region. As can be seen, the reaction region mainly contains interconnected TiC particulates with irregular shape, and the particulates with the size of 2–5 μm are uniformly distributed within the iron matrix. To improve mechanical properties, Han and Kong [12] prepared TiC-based cermet with a core/rim structure by spark plasma sintering, with the addition of TiN nanoparticles. The core consisted of TiC ceramic particulates with the size of <2 μm surrounded by a rim which was a solid solution of (Ti, W, Mo)C. They also pointed out that the growth rate of Ti(C, N) was slower than that of TiC due to the stabilization of TiC phase in the nitrogen environment [13] . Similar microstructure was observed for austenitic stainless steel reinforced with 5 vol.% TiC particulates with the size of 2–10 μm and polygonal morphology [14] . It was noted that the introduction of TiC particulates into the matrix by in situ reaction inhibited the contamination of the interphase boundaries between TiC particulates and the γ-Fe grains. Hui et al. [15] fabricated TiC particulate reinforced Fe–Cr–Ni matrix composites by a liquid state in situ synthesis. Spherical and polyhedral TiC particulates with the size of 0.5–3 μm were uniformly dispersed in austenite matrix. The interface between TiC and austenite in the composite was a coherent interface with the orientation relationship of ( 0 2 ¯ 0 ) λ / / ( 2 2 ¯ 0 ) TiC , [ 001 ] λ | | [ 001 ] TiC . According to the results from an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), the molar ratio of Ti:C calculated from the EDS spectrum is 1:1.04, which is close to 1:1, giving a possible composition of TiC. These results are in good agreement with the XRD data. The thermodynamics of in situ chemical reactions between the molten iron and the titanium was also studied in this work. According to the standard thermodynamic calculations [16,17] , the following reactions might possibly occur during the fabrication of the TiC particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites: (3) Ti + C = TiC Δ G 1 = - 181.251 + 0.013 T ( 25 – 1670 ° C ) (4) 3 Fe + C = Fe 3 C Δ G 2 = 17.984 - 0.019 T ( 727 – 1727 ° C ) (5) Fe + Ti = FeTi Δ G 3 = - 41.261 + 0.012 T ( 727 – 1727 ° C ) (6) 2 Fe + Ti = Fe 2 Ti Δ G 4 = - 90.885 + 0.027 T ( 727 – 1727 ° C ) In order to confirm these reactions, the Gibbs free energies for TiC, Fe 3 C, FeTi, and Fe 2 Ti are calculated and plotted in Fig. 5 as a function of temperature. It can be noted that the Gibbs free energies indicate the negative values above 1138 °C, implying the occurrence of the above-listed reactions. At the reaction temperature of 1138 °C, ΔG 2 is, however, slightly negative with the value of −3.64 kJ mol −1 . That means Fe 3 C is not a thermodynamically-favored product. On the contrary, the value of ΔG 1 is the highest one, presenting TiC to be the most stable product among them. Because the TiC phase started forming when the alloy had not solidified yet, while Fe 3 C, FeTi, and Fe 2 Ti phases precipitated only in the processes of solidification and cooling. So, higher temperature and longer treatment time promoted the dissolution of metallic titanium that further reacted with the carbon atoms to form titanium carbide particles in the iron matrix. On the other hand, higher temperature improved the wettability between liquid phase and TiC reinforcement, which intensified the dissolution-precipitation of TiC particulates. The microhardness distribution in the composites heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h and 11 h is plotted in Fig. 6 as a function of a distance away from the center of the titanium wire. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the highest microhardness value is about 3085 HV 0.1 in the diffusion reaction region (i.e. composite region) after heat treatment of the sample at 1138 °C for 6 h. This is thought to be due mainly to the formation of intensive TiC particulates in this region. The average microhardness of the three main regions can be placed in the following order: 209 HV 0.1 (iron matrix) < 787 HV 0.1 (titanium wire) < 2667 HV 0.1 (composite region). As mentioned before, there is no metallic titanium wire remaining in the center of the reinforcement phase after heat treatment of the sample at 1138 °C for 11 h. Therefore, the microhardness values for the titanium wire do not appear separately in Fig. 6 b. It is worth to mention that with increasing heat treatment time from 6 h to 11 h, the microhardness values of the composite region do not change considerably. The average microhardness value of the composite region in the specimen heat treated at 1138 °C for 11 h is about 2354 HV 0.1 , which is twelve times higher than that of the iron matrix and slightly lower than that of the composite heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h. The relative wear resistance of gray cast iron and specimens heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h and 11 h are comparatively shown in Fig. 7 as a function of applied load. The specimens after heat treatment at 1138 °C for 6 h and 11 h possess wear resistance which is much higher than that of gray cast iron under a 5 N load. That is, the specimen heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h shows relative wear resistance of 12.1 and the specimen heat treated at 1138 °C for 11 h shows relative wear resistance of 14.5, while gray cast iron has relative wear resistance of 1. It can be concluded that the TiC particulates formed in situ play an important role in improvement of mechanical properties of the composites; particularly, they reinforce the iron matrix significantly and protect it from a serious abrasion. It is known that the wear property is normally affected by the ratio of hardness of abrasive material and hardness of the composite material [18,19] . When the ratio is less than 0.80, the abrasion of material is very small, and the abrasion of material is quite high when it is more than 1.25 [20] . The microhardness values of the TiC reinforcement and Al 2 O 3 abrasive paper are 3200 HV and 2600 HV, respectively, and the ratio is nearly 0.81. According to Richardson theory [21] , the abrasion of the as-prepared composites is very small. The wear morphologies of gray cast iron and specimens heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h and 11 h under a 5 N load are shown in Fig. 8 . Probably, these are the results of the combined effects of microcutting and microploughing. As Sun et al. [22] reported, the wear mechanisms of the TiCp/Fe composites appear as microcutting and microploughing, and partly microcracking. Due to less structural defects, microcracking in the as-prepared composites cannot be easily observed. In addition, microcutting and microploughing are normally the dominant interactions in more ductile materials. They are connected with high deformation of the surface worn. In general, the existence of microcracks is closely related to the formation of spalling pits. When the stress concentration at the interface between the reinforcement and the matrix reaches a certain value, a microcrack will be nucleated and with the growth of the microcracks, the TiC reinforcement particle would spall off and leave a spalling pit on the surface [22] . Moreover, when the abrasive particles fracture, it tends to generate fresh sharp cutting edge, increasing particle angularity [23] . An increasing particle angularity favors the more damaging microcutting abrasion mechanism over the less damaging microploughing mechanism. Hence, high-stress abrasion occurs when the sharp-edge small abrasive particles scratch the surface [24] . As demonstrated by Zum Gahr [20] , the ration of depth penetration allows distinguishing between different abrasive mechanisms, i.e. microcutting and microploughing. It is also visible that each specimen possesses grooves but the grooves in the specimens heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h and 11 h are much narrower and shallower compared to those in gray cast iron. This is attributed to the formation of TiC reinforcement phase in the iron matrix which blocks the abrasion paths during the wear test. Due to the difference in microhardness and wear resistance values, the difference in the grooves in the two composite specimens is still noticeable. It can be summarized that the relative wear resistance of the specimen heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h is less than that of the specimen heat treated at 1138 °C for 11 h. 4 Conclusions Titanium carbide (TiC) particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites were in situ fabricated by a combined method of infiltration casting and a subsequent heat treatment. The effects of different heat treatment times (0, 1, 6 and 11 h) at 1138 °C on the phase evolution, microstructural features, and properties of the composites were investigated. The XRD results showed that the composites consisted of graphite, α-iron and titanium carbide after heat treatment at 1138 °C for 11 h. The SEM observation revealed that the formed TiC particulates were homogenously distributed in the iron matrix. The average microhardness value of the composite heat treated at 1138 °C for 6 h increased depending upon the region: 209 HV 0.1 (iron matrix) < 787 HV 0.1 (titanium wire) < 2667 HV 0.1 (composite region). After being heat treated at 1138 °C for 11 h, the composite indicated a slight change in microhardness value, and the average microhardness value of the composite region was about 2354 HV 0.1 . The highest microhardness value obtained in the composite region was due to the formation of hard titanium carbide particulates as reinforcement phase within the iron matrix. Relative wear resistance was determined by a pin-on-disc wear test technique, and as a result, the composites containing higher volume fraction of hard titanium carbide particulates presented higher wear resistance compared with the unreinforced gray cast iron. UhhEQQ22.title: Study on NbC particulate-reinforced iron matrix composite produced in situ
UhhEQQ22.abstract:
In the infiltration casting process and heat treatment method, gray cast iron and niobium wires are compounded. The reinforcement
 phase NbC particles are synthesized in situ between niobium wires and graphite phases in the gray cast iron using heat treatment.
 The microstructure and micro-hardness of the compound region are observed and measured through X-ray diffraction, scanning
 electron microscopy, and micro-hardness testing. The results indicate that at 1172 °C for 25 min, the in situ reaction area
 is diffusely extended eight times larger than the original diameter of 0.7 mm. The NbC particles synthesized in situ are tiny
 square- or rectangle-like particles that are evenly distributed in the gray cast iron. The highest micro-hardness value of
 the composite region is 1988 HV0.05, and the average micro-hardness value of the composite region after 20 min heat treatment is 953 HV0.05 or about five times larger than that of the matrix. After heat treatment at 1172 °C for 25 min, the average micro-hardness
 value of the composite was about 458 HV0.05, and the average macro-hardness was 49.2 HRC.

CgTxaNaJ.title: Infiltration casting and in situ fabrication of tantalum carbide particulate-reinforced iron matrix composites
CgTxaNaJ.abstract: Reinforced tantalum carbide particles were synthesized between tantalum wires and graphite in gray cast iron by heat treatment; the effects of different heat treatment times on the phase evolution, microstructure, and micro-hardness of the composites were investigated. The particles obtained were small and square-shaped, 1-2 μm in size, and evenly distributed through the cast iron. The maximum micro-hardness of the composite region was 1832 HV0.1. After 20 min heat treatment, the micro-hardness decreased to approximately 1077 HV0.1, between about four and five times that of the matrix. The resulting composites also presented higher wear resistance compared with unreinforced gray cast iron. © The Author(s) 2011.

mqJtNhPv.title: In situ NbC particulate-reinforced iron matrix composite: Microstructure and abrasive wear characteristics
mqJtNhPv.abstract: An niobium carbide (NbC) particle-reinforced iron matrix composite was fabricated by compounding gray cast iron with niobium wires through an in situ technique comprised of an infiltration casting process and a subsequent heat treatment. The NbC particles in the reinforcement phase were synthesized in situ through the reaction between niobium from niobium wires and carbon from the graphite phases produced by the heat treatment in gray cast iron. The microstructure and wear-resistance of the bulk niobium particle-reinforced iron matrix composite was studied at different NbC particle volume fractions (8, 15, 22, and 28 vol%), by scanning electron microscope, X-ray diffraction, and a wear tester. The NbC particles were observed to form tiny cuboids and nearly spherical particles which were evenly distributed in the matrix. The particle size of the NbC reinforcement was about 0.3-3.5 μm. The relative wear resistance of the bulk composite increased with increasing NbC volume fraction, and the wear resistance of the composite was 5.9-fold higher than that of the gray cast iron under a 20N load and at a 28 vol% volume fraction. Wear performance of the composite at different NbC particle volume fraction values was also analyzed. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.

BeKzUKql.title: Abrasive wear characteristics of in-situ TiC-reinforced iron matrix surface gradient composites
BeKzUKql.abstract: An in-situ synthesis process combining an infilxtration casting with a following heating treatment was applied to fabricate special titanium carbide (TiC) particles-reinforced iron matrix surface gradient composites in this article. The microstructure and wear-resistance of the titanium carbide particle reinforced iron matrix surface gradient composites were researched by using differential scanning calorimetry, X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and abrasive wear testing. The results showed that two materials had been reacted completely between the titanium plate and gray cast iron, and the titanium carbide particles distributed in the matrix with the thickness of 266.7 μm reaction layer. The average size of titanium carbide between titanium plate and iron matrix was about 1-2μm. Under the same condition, the wear mechanism of titanium carbide particles-reinforced iron matrix surface gradient composites appeared as: micro-ploughing, micro-cutting and broken titanium carbide. © (2012) Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.

TQJ9ag4X.title: Fabrication and microstructure of in situ vanadium carbide ceramic particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites
TQJ9ag4X.abstract: In this work, a novel process that combines infiltration casting with subsequent heat treatment was applied to fabricate in situ vanadium carbide (V 8C 7) ceramic particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites. Based on the differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) data, the as-cast samples were subjected to heat treatment at 1164 °C for different dwelling times (0, 10, 15, and 20 min). The effects of different heat treatment times on the phase evolution, microstructure, and microhardness of the as-prepared composites were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS), and Vickers hardness tester, respectively. The experimental results revealed that only graphite, α-Fe, and V 8C 7 phases dominate in the composite samples after heat treatment at 1164 °C for 20 min. The average microhardness of the as-prepared composites varied among the different regions as follows: 458 HV 0.05 (vanadium wire), 1055 HV 0.05 (composite area), and 235 HV 0.05 (iron matrix). The microhardness of the composite region is four times higher than that of the iron matrix and two times higher than that of the vanadium wire because of the formation of the vanadium carbide phases (V 2C and V 8C 7) as reinforcement within the iron matrix. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd and Techna Group S.r.l.

cZaq4p7P.title: Microstructure of matrix and wear resistance of ceramic layer of TiC/Fe surface gradient composites
cZaq4p7P.abstract: In this paper, the joining of gray cast iron (HT300) and titanium plate with the thickness of 0.25 mm was performed by the method of pouring. The sample was isothermal-ly kept in vacuum tube furnace at 1 138°C for 8 h, and cooled in furnace to room temperature. TiC particulates reinforced surface gradient composite was prepared on the iron matrix of cast i-ron surface by the in-situ technology. Microstructure analysis, microhardness and wear-resistance test were carried out on the recombination region. The experimental results show that the TiC particulates reinforced surface gradient composite is composed of three layers. The difference between the three layers lies in the different sizes and different shapes of TiC particulates. The microhardness decreases gradually from composite layer (C region) to pearlite region. The maximum microhardness appears in the high density ceramic layer (C region). Therefore, wear experiment was further performed to study wear-resistance of the high density ceramic layer of the surface gradient composite. Apparently, the wear-resistance of high density ceramic layer is enhanced greatly in comparison with gray cast iron.

ae3R5FEH.title: Microstructure, microhardness and wear resistance of VCp/Fe surface composites fabricated in situ
ae3R5FEH.abstract: The vanadium carbide particles (VCp)/Fe surface composites were in situ fabricated by a technique combining infiltration casting with subsequent heat treatment. The effects of different heat treatment times on the phase evolution, microstructure, microhardness and wear resistance of the composite were studied by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Vickers hardness tester and wear resistance testing instrument, respectively. The results show that only graphite, α-Fe and V 8C7 phases dominate in the composite after being heat treated at 1164 C for 3 h. The amount of V8C7 decreases gradually from the top surface of the composite to the matrix mainly composed of gray cast iron. The average microhardness of the VCp/Fe surface composites varies according to the different reaction zones as follows: 505 HV0.1 (vanadium plate), 1096 HV0.1 (composite region), and 235 HV0.1 (iron matrix). The microhardness of the composite region is four times higher than that of the iron matrix and two times higher than that of the vanadium plate. This is attributed to the formation of vanadium carbide (V2C and V8C7) crystallites as reinforcement phases within the iron matrix. The VCp/Fe surface composites exhibit a good wear resistance under two-body abrasive wear test. ©2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

islChVwc.title: Microstructure and abrasive wear characteristics of in situ vanadium carbide particulate-reinforced iron matrix composites
islChVwc.abstract: In this work, in situ synthesis with infiltration casting and subsequent heat treatment was applied to fabricate vanadium carbide (V8C7) particulate-reinforced iron matrix composites. The microstructure and wear-resistance of V8C7 particulate-reinforced iron matrix composites with different volume fraction were studied using scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and wear testing. The V8C7 particles were uniformly distributed in the matrix, and the size of the V8C7 reinforcement was 2-12��m. The relative wear resistance of the composites initially increases decreases with higher V8C7 volume fractions. The best wear resistance of the composites was 21.2 times higher than that of gray cast iron under a 20N load. This was achieved at 24% V8C7 volume fraction. Wear of the composites manifests as grooves, broken carbide particles, and re-embedment of wear debris. ? 2013 Elsevier Ltd.

j1qc54Tp.title: Infiltration casting and in-situ fabrication of NbC particulates - Reinforced iron matrix composites
j1qc54Tp.abstract: Niobium carbide (NbC) particulates-reinforced iron matrix composites were prepared by in-situ fabrication method combining an infiltration casting with a subsequent heat treatment. The microstructure and wear-resistance of NbC particulate-reinforced iron matrix composites were studied using scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and wear testing. The results indicate that at 1172 °C for 3 hours NbC particulate-reinforced iron matrix composites were fabricated, and the size of NbC reinforcement was 0.3-3.5 μm. The relative wear resistance of the composites was 5.4 times higher than that of gray cast iron under a 20 N load. This was achieved at 22 % NbC volume fraction. Wear of the composites manifests as grooves, broken carbide particulates and some micro-cracks. © (2011) Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.

jV25lEY8.title: Infiltration casting and in-situ fabrication of (Fe,Cr) 7C 3 particulates bundle - Reinforced iron matrix composites
jV25lEY8.abstract: The method of infiltration casting plus heat treatment process employing chromium wires and cast iron applied to in-situ synthesized (Fe,Cr) 7C 3 particulates bundle reinforced iron matrix composites. The phase analysis, microstructure, microhardness and wear-resistance of composite were observed and measured. The results show that it is possible to fabricate (Fe,Cr) 7C 3 particulates bundle reinforced iron matrix composite produced by this technology, and a special structure which called particulates bundle was fabricated. (Fe,Cr) 7C 3 particulates bundle were distributed in the forms of granular, lath-shaped and hexagon-shaped in the particulates bundle. The macrohardness of particulates bundle was 52 HRC, and the relative wear resistance of the composites is 2.3 - 23 times higher than that of the cast iron. © (2011) Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.

2DM30CiA.title: Microstructure and abrasive wear characteristics of in-situ WC bundles - Reinforced iron matrix composites
2DM30CiA.abstract: An in-situ synthesis process combining an infiltration casting with a subsequent heat treatment was applied to fabricate special tungsten carbide (WC) bundles-reinforced iron matrix composites in this work. The microstructure and wear-resistance of the tungsten carbide bundles reinforced iron matrix composites were studied by using scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction and wear tester. Results showed that the tungsten carbide bundles distributed in the matrix with the center-to-center spacing 2.2 mm, and the diameter of each tungsten carbide bundle is about 1 mm. Most of the tungsten carbides agglomerated, but still there were tungsten carbide particles and the size of tungsten carbide particle was about 10 - 15 μm. The weight loss of the tungsten carbides bundle reinforced iron matrix composites increased with the increase of the loads and the weight loss of the composites is much less than those of the gray cast iron under the same condition. The wear mechanism of tungsten carbide bundles-reinforced iron matrix composites appears as: micro-cutting, micro-ploughing, broken tungsten carbide and broken particles re-embedded in the matrix. © (2011) Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.

eaarbui1.title: Effect of SDS on morphology tailoring of GdVO4:Eu3+ powders under hydrothermal conditions in a wide pH range
eaarbui1.abstract: Europium doped micro-/nano-crystalline gadolinium vanadate (GdVO 4:Eu3+) powders were successfully fabricated via a facile hydrothermal route. To investigate the influences of sodium dodecyl sulfonate (SDS) and pH on the morphology and luminescent properties of GdVO 4:Eu3+ phosphors, different amounts of SDS were added in the hydrothermal reaction system under various pH values. The structures and morphologies of the final products were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Several interesting morphologies of GdVO4:Eu 3+ powders were obtained, including tetragonal, octahedron, rod-like, and dendritic. The results indicated that the pH determines the nucleation rate of GdVO4:Eu3+ crystals in the solution, and the SDS affects the crystal growth pattern by changing growth direction and forming micelles. Moreover, possible mechanisms for morphological evolution are also presented. The photoluminescent (PL) properties of the products were also characterized. All the samples exhibited the characteristic fluorescence of Eu3+ ion. In addition, the intensities of excitation and emission spectra varied with the morphological change. The product with nanocrystal morphology showed the strongest PL intensity among all the samples with different morphologies. Besides, the PL property was enhanced with good crystalline state, but weakened by serious aggregation. ? 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

5sAsH872.title: Nonionic surfactant-assisted hydrothermal synthesis of YVO 4:Eu3+ powders in a wide pH range and their luminescent properties
5sAsH872.abstract: YVO 4 :Eu 3+ powders with different morphologies were fabricated by a simple hydrothermal method at 180 °C for 24 h in a wide pH range with the assistance of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as a nonionic surfactant. The as-synthesized samples were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and photoluminescence spectroscopy (PL). The obtained results showed that the pH value of synthesis solution played a key role in the formation of final products with different morphologies, such as, microspheres, irregular microspheres with grain-like nanoparticles, stone-like structures with regular short nanorods, and smooth rhombohedrons. The PL measurements revealed that the emission intensity of the samples was first decreased, and then increased with increasing the pH value due mainly to the increase in crystallinity and decrease in surface defects. Keywords Optical materials Hydrothermal synthesis Electron microscopy Luminescence

u5lp0BOj.title: Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)-assisted hydrothermal synthesis of luminescent YVO4:Eu3+ microspheres
u5lp0BOj.abstract: Spherical YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microstructures were hydrothermally synthesized by the reaction of NH 4 VO 3 , Y 2 O 3 , and Eu 2 O 3 at 180 °C for 24 h with the assistance of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as a surfactant. The resulting products were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy. The experimental results showed that ball-like YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microspheres with a diameter of about 4–5 μm, corresponding to the SEM observations, formed at 180 °C for 24 h using 0.2 g PVP with the molecular weight of 20,000 g mol −1 . The amount of PVP and the reaction time of hydrothermal processing were found to play a key role in the formation of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microspheres. It has been observed that the relative luminescence intensities of the as-synthesized samples increased with increasing hydrothermal reaction times due mainly to the increase of crystallinity. Keywords Microspheres Optical material Photoluminescence spectroscopy 1 Introduction Spherical nanostructures and microstructures, including hollow and plain spheres, have been intensively studied owing to their unique properties derived from their specific morphologies. In general, a spherically well-dispersed morphology is an important factor for low-light scattering at the surfaces and high-packing densities [1,2] . Moreover, the assembling of low-dimensional particles to form a well-dispersed sphere is a key step towards controlling the collective properties of the particles, which are essential in the fabrication of 2D- and/or 3D-arrayed photonic crystals, nano- and micro-electronic devices, optics, catalysis, sensors, etc. Recently, several research groups have succeeded in developing nanocrystals with a high degree of dispersity and size uniformity. It was found that well-dispersed semiconductors having narrow size distribution and specific morphologies often show considerable optical and electrical properties. An important optical material, yttrium orthovanadate (YVO 4 ) can be applied in various devices involving the artificial production of light and display fields, such as an excellent polarizer [3,4] and a laser host material [5,6] due to its exceptional characteristics such as excellent thermal, mechanical and optical properties. In particular, Eu 3+ -doped YVO 4 has been extensively used as a red-emitting phosphor in color television and cathode ray tubes (CRTs) because of its high luminescence efficiency upon electron-beam excitation [7,8] . In recent years, research has been focused on the processing methods of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ , such as conventional solid-state [9] , hydrothermal [10–13] , hydrolyzed colloidal reaction [14] , and precipitation [15] . Compared with the other methods, the synthesis of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ powder through a hydrothermal route offers several advantages, e.g., high purity, narrow particle size distribution, and precise composition; in addition, this method does not require further heat treatment at high temperatures. Morphology and size of the particles can also be tailored via the hydrothermal processing by adjusting the source species, reaction temperature, reaction time, etc. In sum, this method of synthesizing inorganic materials with specific morphologies seems to be the most promising. A variety of surfactants have been widely used in hydrothermal synthesis to control the chemistry of the process, lowering processing temperatures, reducing surface tension, and regulating nucleation and crystal growth. Wu et al. [16] have successfully prepared the rod-like, olive-like, and pineapple-like nanocrystals of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ under hydrothermal conditions using cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (C 19 H 42 BrN) as a surfactant. Recently, Chen et al. [17] reported that the morphology of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ nanocrystallites can be controlled by varying the pH value (8–14) in the basic solution and increasing luminescence intensity from bundle-like to rice-like to rhombus-like nanocrystals. However, the irregularity and agglomeration of particles still remain a challenging topic. In this paper, we describe a facile route to synthesize YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microspheres by the self-aggregation/assembling of low-dimensional particles under hydrothermal conditions at temperatures as low as 180 °C for 24 h using polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as a nonionic surfactant. The influences of the PVP amounts and hydrothermal reaction times on the morphology and luminescent properties of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microspheres were investigated in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Y 0.95 Eu 0.05 VO 4 microspheres Y 0.95 Eu 0.05 VO 4 microspheres were fabricated via a surfactant-assisted hydrothermal method. All chemical reagents were analytical grade and purchased from Beijing Chemical Reagents Company (China), and used without further purification. Typically, the stoichiometric amounts of Y 2 O 3 , Eu 2 O 3 , and NH 4 VO 3 were dissolved in 25 mL HNO 3 (1 mol L −1 ). An appropriate amount of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was introduced into the solution as a nonionic complex agent and stirred for 10 min to form a yellow-colored mixture. The pH of the resulting solution was adjusted to ∼1 by a drop-wise addition of sodium hydroxide solution under vigorous stirring. The well-stirred mixture thus obtained was then transferred a 40 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a filling capacity of 70%. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C for reaction times of 6, 12 and 24 h. As the autoclave naturally cooled down to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered, washed with distilled water several times, and then dried in a vacuum at 80 °C for 10 h. 2.2 Characterization The phase identification of the as-prepared powders was carried out by X-ray powder diffraction (Model D/MAX 2550 V, Rigaku Co., Tokyo, Japan) with monochromated Cu Kα radiation ( λ = 1.5406 Å) at 40 kV and 50 mA. The morphology and crystalline size of the as-synthesized samples were observed using a scanning electron microscopy (FEI Quanta 200 ESEM, The Netherlands). The excitation and emission photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured using a Perkin-Elmer LS55 fluorescence spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer, Shelton, USA). 3 Results and discussion According to Ropp and Carroll [18] , the form of vanadium ions is extremely sensitive to the pH of the solution, and the vanadium ions exist as VO 2 + when the solution is strongly acidic. When the pH rises to 2, vanadium ions exist principally in the form of V 10 O 28 6− ; when the pH further increases to 5, vanadium ions are likely to appear in the form of V 3 O 9 3− . VO 4 3− exists in the solution when the pH value is >7. In our case, since the pH of the solution is 1, the following reactions may occur: Y 2 O 3 + E u 2 O 3 + HN O 3 → Y ( N O 3 ) 3 + Eu ( N O 3 ) 3 + H 2 O V O 2 + + E u 3 + + Y 3 + ⟶ hydrothermal   process YV O 4 : E u 3 + ( pH   1 ) The XRD patterns of the final products synthesized using PVP with different molecular weights (10,000 and 20000 g mol −1 ) at 180 °C for 24 h are shown in Fig. 1 . The XRD patterns of the samples can be readily indexed to YVO 4 , having a zirconia-type tetragonal structure (JCPDS Card No.17-0341). This confirms that a pure phase YVO 4 :Eu 3+ can be prepared by a simple hydrothermal method at 180 °C for 24 h using PVP with different molecular weights. The SEM images of the products obtained at 180 °C for 24 h using PVP with different molecular weights are illustrated in Fig. 2 which shows that YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microspheres with a fewer twinning spheres were formed under the current conditions. Apparently, the product with large-scale uniform ball-like microspheres shows a regular morphology and a good crystalline state with a diameter in the range of 4–5 μm ( Fig. 2 b). The SEM observation recommends the use of PVP with molecular weight of 20,000 g mol −1 for further experiments due to its favorable characteristics. Fig. 3 presents XRD patterns of the products obtained at 180 °C for 24 h using PVP with the amounts of 0.1, 0.2, and 0.4. All XRD patterns can be readily indexed as a zirconia-type tetragonal structure, approaching the standard values for the bulk YVO 4 (JCPDS Card No. 17-0341). The SEM micrographs of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ phosphors obtained at 180 °C for 24 h using PVP with the amounts of 0.1, 0.2, and 0.4 g are displayed in Fig. 4 which shows that all samples have a plain spherical morphology with a submicrometer size. Fig. 4 a shows a SEM image of the as-synthesized samples with 0.1 g PVP. Visually, the samples are irregular microspheres comprised of several small particles tending to agglomeration. By increasing the amount of PVP to 0.2 g, large-scale uniform ball-like microspheres with smooth surfaces ( Fig. 4 b) were formed. The particles have an average size of about 4–5 μm in diameter. The surface of the phosphors is very smooth, which is very important to obtain a high efficiency. A smooth, defect-free phosphor surface can decrease the non-radiation and scattering that result from a coarse surface and can also increase the luminescence efficiency. Further increase in the amount of PVP to 0.4 g resulted in longitudinal growth and increasing aspect ratio. A large number of cobblestone-like YVO 4 :Eu 3+ powders including irregular particles were formed with an average aspect ratio of about 1.5 and a diameter of 2–3 μm ( Fig. 4 c). Therefore, on the basis of the SEM results, it can be concluded that varying the amount of PVP in the growth solution is a crucial step to control the morphology of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ . A 0.2 g PVP was found to be optimal for obtaining the pure ball-like YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microspheres with a uniform diameter of about 4–5 μm due to homogeneous precipitation. It is well known that the addition of a complex agent can affect the nucleation and crystal growth, which consequently modifies particle morphology and size. A strong ligand is used not only to form a stable complex with Y 3+ , but also to bind to the surface of the crystal, which directly affects the growth direction and crystal structure. Here, homogeneous precipitation is a type of hydrothermal precipitation method that has been widely used to synthesize nanomaterials with superior homogeneity and particle size uniformity [19–22] . This homogeneous precipitation method can also be used to prepare spherical particles [23,24] . In this paper, when the amount of PVP was 0.1 g, the homogeneous precipitation was complete, but the nucleus growing into spherical particles was incomplete due to the lesser amount of PVP. By increasing the amount of PVP to 0.2 g, the nucleus grows into large spherical particles that can be ultimately crystallized thereby resulting in the formation of very fine spherical crystals. This result may indicate that the homogeneous precipitation is active due to the simultaneous adhesion of water and PVP, dissolving, and reprecipitating to yield well-dispersed particles. When the amount of PVP was 0.4 g, there were fewer homogeneous nuclei because of the excessive unreacted amount of PVP. When this mixture was hydrothermally processed under certain pressure and temperature, the excessive PVP acted as a soft template, so cobblestone-like phosphors were obtained. The effect of the hydrothermal reaction time, or so-called crystallizing time, on the morphology and phase composition of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ was also investigated. Fig. 5 shows typical XRD patterns of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ hydrothermally synthesized at 180 °C for the reaction times of 6, 12 and 24 h. All XRD patterns can be readily indexed to a zirconia-type tetragonal structure with lattice constants comparable to the values given in JCPDS 17-0341; no traces of other phases could be detected. The results show that pure phase YVO 4 :Eu 3+ can be obtained under hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C for 6 h and the diffraction intensities of the samples increase with an increasing hydrothermal reaction time up to 24 h which means the samples become a highly crystallized with a longer reaction time. Fig. 6 shows the SEM micrographs of the YVO 4 :Eu 3+ powders hydrothermally synthesized at 180 °C for the reaction times of 6, 12 and 24 h. Apparently, the hydrothermal reaction time has a significant impact on the morphology of the as-synthesized products. A better crystalline state was obtained with a longer hydrothermal reaction time. The morphology of samples prepared at 180 °C for 6 h ( Fig. 6 a) is spherical with irregular particles and a fewer twinning spheres. Spherical particles with a size of several hundred nanometers could be found, but the edge was not clear. With the hydrothermal reaction time of 12 h ( Fig. 6 b), a regular structure appeared, but the microspheres were still not uniform and smooth which means that an improvement of crystallinity is required. When the hydrothermal reaction time reached 24 h, the samples showed a regular shape of a particle with smooth surface. The SEM results indicate that a hydrothermal reaction time of 24 h is the optimum under the current conditions. The reason for the formation of spherical phosphors with a regular shape and smooth surface may be attributed to the homogeneous precipitation process in the first step and to the homogeneous nucleation and growth in the aging process with an appropriate amount of PVP. The PL spectra of the products were measured using a fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature. Fig. 7 shows PL excitation spectra of the Y 0.95 Eu 0.05 VO 4 samples synthesized at 180 °C for 24 h with different amounts of PVP (0.1, 0.2, and 0.4 g) under the emission of 618 nm. All the excitation spectra are approximately identical and consist of a broad band ranging from 200 to 350 nm with a maximum peak at about 303 nm and some weak lines in the longer wavelength region. This result can be attributed to the absorption of the VO 4 3− group and the latter to the f–f transitions within the Eu 3+ 4f 6 configuration. The excitation spectrum with the highest intensity was obtained for the samples with 0.2 g PVP. Similarly, YVO 4 :Eu 3+ powders prepared with different hydrothermal reaction times (6, 12, and 24 h) show a broad absorption bands in the range of 200–350 nm with a maximum peak at about 303 nm due to the absorption of the VO 4 3− group ( Fig. 8 ). In the longer wavelength (350–500 nm), the weak bands also confirm the f–f transitions of Eu 3+ ions. The PL emission spectra of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ samples synthesized with different amounts of PVP (0.1, 0.2, and 0.4 g) under the excitation of 303 nm are represented in Fig. 9 . The spectra composed of sharp lines ranging from 500 to 700 nm are associated with the transitions from the excited 5 D 0 level to 7 F J ( J = 1, 2, 3) levels of Eu 3+ activators. The emission bands around 590 nm could be ascribed to the 5 D 0 → 7 F 1 magnetic dipole transitions; the weak peak at 538.5 nm is related to the transition from 5 D 1 to 7 F 1 . Meanwhile, the emission peaks located at about 618 nm are mainly due to the transitions from a 5 D 0 to 7 F 2 energy level. The 5 D 0 → 7 F 2 transition is a forced electronic dipole–dipole transition and hypersensitive to the environment. Their high intensities are a consequence of the absence of an inversion symmetry at the Eu 3+ lattice site ( D 2d symmetry) [16,19] . Here, the solid samples of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ hydrothermally synthesized are optical material. It is reasonable to compare luminescence intensities for YVO 4 :Eu 3+ samples. Many published papers have detailed discussions about solid optical materials; for example, Zhou and Lin [25] and Yan and Su [26] have fabricated different solid samples and compared their luminescent characteristics. The emission intensity of the peaks increased gradually when the morphology changed from irregular microspheres to uniform microspheres. We attribute this intensity change of the predominant peak to the distinct microstructure of these microspheres. Irregular and cobblestone-like microspheres possess a larger surface area and higher surface energy, which not only form the main impetus for assembly, but also result in a higher degree of disorder and corresponding lower symmetry of crystal fields around the Eu 3+ ions. It is known that the 5 D 0 → 7 F 2 transition is highly sensitive to structural change and environmental effects. The difference of the 5 D 0 → 7 F 2 emission peak in relative intensity is due to the difference in the effects of the crystal field perturbation on the individual f–f transitions. On the other hand, as the samples were prepared in water, the surface of the YVO 4 may be covered with hydroxyl species, which act as efficient quenchers of the excited Eu 3+ ions. The absorption between quenching species and crystal surfaces is affected by the sizes and shapes of YVO 4 , so the differences in the PL intensity of the samples may be attributed to the different quenching abilities of the adsorbed species on the surface to the emission from Eu 3+ ions. When the amount of PVP is 0.2 g, the luminescence intensity of the uniform and smooth microspheres is at its strongest. This result indicates that an efficient transfer to the rare earth ions occurs, perhaps because the nanostructures can prevent the adsorbed species on the surface from quenching the emissions from the Eu 3+ ions and crystal fields around the Eu 3+ ions which possess well order and symmetry. So we can further confirm that Eu 3+ occupies the host lattice and replaces Y 3+ . Therefore, the Eu 3+ dopant in uniform YVO 4 microspheres leads to a noticeable improvement in the luminescent properties. The emission spectra of the products obtained at 180 °C for different hydrothermal reaction times (6, 12, and 24 h) are shown in Fig. 10 . All the emission spectra of YVO 4 :Eu 3+ powders show similar features despite the varying the reaction times. Upon excitation of 303 nm, the emission spectra are also associated with transitions from the excited 5 D 0 level to 7 F J ( J = 1, 2, 3) levels of Eu 3+ activators. The emission intensity of the microspheres increases by increasing the hydrothermal reaction time due to an increase in the crystallinity and particles size, which is in good agreement with the XRD and SEM results. Therefore, by changing the morphology of the powders, the luminescent properties of the YVO 4 :Eu 3+ phosphors can be effectively controlled using PVP as an effective surfactant. 4 Conclusions Large-scale and well-dispersed YVO 4 :Eu microspheres were synthesized by a PVP-assisted hydrothermal process at 180 °C for 24 h. The effect of the PVP amount and hydrothermal reaction time on the morphology of the as-synthesized product was investigated in detail. The experimental results reveal that YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microspheres (4–5 μm) with regular shape and smooth surface can be obtained using 0.2 g PVP with a molecular weight of 20,000 g mol −1 at 180 °C for 24 h under hydrothermal conditions. The excitation and emission intensities of the YVO 4 :Eu 3+ microspheres had a strong dependence on the hydrothermal reaction time due to the increase of crystallinity. This low-temperature synthetic route, involving no catalysts and requiring no precise equipment, can be easily adjusted to prepare YVO 4 crystals on a large scale. Simultaneously realizing a shape-controlled synthesis of microspheres is exciting and challenging; the resulting structures and sizes are both scientifically and technically important, which is the foundation for practical application.
